China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Mn4+ shows great potential in low-temperature SCR process due to its excellent redox properties, but Mn4+ is not easy to recover after participating in the SCR reaction, and realizing valence cycling of Mn ions to stabilize the content of high valence Mn4+ is still an urgent problem to be solved. In this work, a high valence Mn4+ catalyst was prepared and Cr was introduced to utilize the electron transfer between Mn and Cr to effectively realize the regeneration and content stabilization of Mn4+. The experimental results showed that the MnCr-3 catalyst with abundant Mn4+ exhibited excellent low-temperature denitrification performance and water and sulfur resistance, and the XPS study demonstrated that the regeneration of Mn4+ was achieved by the presence of electron transfer between Mn and Cr in the SCR reaction of the MnCr-3 catalyst. And a series of characterizations showed that the MnCr-3 catalyst with abundant high-valent Mn4+ exhibited excellent redox properties and acidity. Finally, in situ DRIFTS experiments explored the NH3-SCR reaction mechanism and water and sulfur resistance mechanism of the catalysts. Graphical abstract In this work, high valence manganese-chromium composite oxide catalytic system was prepared by hydrothermal oxidation. It was found that the electron transfer between Mn and Cr in the MnCr-3 catalyst could achieve the regeneration of highly active species Mn4+ and stabilize its content. The abundant high-valent Mn4+ in the MnCr-3 catalyst enabled the catalyst to exhibit excellent redox performance, promoted the oxidation of NO to NO2, and significantly enhanced the low-temperature SCR performance through the “fast SCR” reaction. In situ DRIFTS studies showed that the MnCr-3 catalyst follows the l-H mechanism during the whole reaction process. Image, graphical abstract Keywords NH3-SCR High valence state Mn4+ Low-temperature Water and sulfur resistance In situ DRIFTS Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx), blamed for deteriorating air conditions, largely originate from motor vehicle exhaust and the combustion of fossil fuels. The extensive emission of NOx has triggered various severe environmental issues, for instance, photochemical smog, acid rain, ozone layer destruction, etc., which have drawn extensive attention from all walks of life in the world [1,2]. To cope with the many harmful effects of nitrogen oxides on human beings, NOx emissions need to be strictly controlled, and various attempts have been made to this end. In particular, NH3 selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) strategy has already been extensively employed for many years and has become the most established and dependable approach to removing NOx [3,4]. Currently, the V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2 catalysts exhibit superior catalytic properties in the medium and high temperature ranges and are widely applied for efficient NO removal [5,6]. To maximize the catalytic performance of vanadium-based catalysts, the NH3-SCR denitrification systems must be installed in front of the dust collector and the desulfurization unit, but in this case, the catalyst is prone to be deactivated by the toxicity of substances in the flue gas such as dust and SO2 [7,8]. Low-temperature (LT) catalysts can be utilized for efficient denitrification at low temperatures, making it possible to install the denitrification device following the dust catcher and desulfurization systems. Hence, studying and developing low-temperature and high-activity NH3-SCR denitrification catalysts is of far-reaching value. In recent years, many transition metal oxide catalysts have been extensively investigated for their LT denitrification performance, such as V2O5/TiO2 [9], V/Mo-Ti [10], FeOx [11], MnOx [12], MnOx–CeO2 [13]. One of them, Mn-based catalysts, because of their multivalent states and superior redox characteristics, have performed outstandingly in LT denitrification reactions, and have been widely noticed and researched in the field of denitrification in recent years [14–16]. Since the NO conversion of MnOx catalysts is governed by factors such as Mnn+ valence state, crystal type, morphology, and exposure surface, for this reason, researchers have carried out a large number of studies around these factors. Mn ions have many different valence states, and MnOx catalysts with different oxidation states exhibit different NH3-SCR performances. Kapteijn et al. [17] prepared pure MnOx catalysts of different oxidation states for low-temperature SCR tests and found that Mn oxides with higher valence states exhibit higher SCR reactivity. Different oxidation states of MnOx exhibited the following order of reactivity in the NH3-SCR reaction: MnO2 > Mn5O8 > Mn2O3 > Mn3O4 > MnO. Among the various Mn oxides, MnO2 with high-valent state, shows the strongest oxidizing ability. According to the literature, the high valence Mn4+ can promote the oxidation of NO to NO2, induce the “fast SCR” reaction, and enhance the low-temperature denitrification performance of the catalyst [18]. Numerous experiments have confirmed that high-valent Mn4+ ions perform most actively in the NH3-SCR. It has been found that the valence states of the active components of catalysts are affected by the preparation method, and thus catalysts obtained by different preparation methods tend to exhibit different catalytic abilities [19]. Therefore, the valence of metal ions and the content of each valence in the catalytic materials may differ from the prepared method. Although the SCR performance of high valence Mn4+ in pure MnOx catalysts is promising, it is unstable and can be easily reduced to Mn3+ with the catalytic reaction and cannot be recovered, thus limiting the application of pure MnOx catalysts in denitrification field. In order to solve the above problem, researchers have focused on the construction of composite oxide catalytic systems. Many research works have introduced other active metal oxides (MOx) like FeOx, CoOx, NiOx and CeOx as co-catalysts toward Mn-based catalysts for modification, which effectively enhance the SCR performance of the catalytic system through the electron transfer between Mnn+ and Mn+ [20–22]. Cr has been extensively studied in denitrification reactions because of its great redox capacity and SO2 tolerance [23]. Based on this, this paper considers the preparation of a bimetallic catalyst system by doping Cr oxides into Mn-based catalysts. Attempts were made to regenerate and stabilize the content of the active species Mn4+ through the strong contacts between the two metal ions and the electron transfer process, so as to achieve a better low-temperature denitrification performance. What needs to be emphasized is that, in general, the catalyst's Mn4+concentration, specific surface area, redox capacity, surface acidity and acid strength, and surface chemisorbed oxygen all significantly affect how well it performs in NOx removal. For example, in the LT NH3-SCR process, the magnitude of Mn4+ concentration is crucial for the conversion of NO, and its decreased concentration contributes to the catalyst's inactivity at low temperatures. Hence, the design of a catalytic system containing high content of high valence Mn4+ is significant to achieve good low-temperature denitrification performance and water and sulfur resistant properties. In this work, a high valence state manganese-chromium catalytic system was designed for low temperature NH3-SCR reaction. Two additional low valence state samples were made available for comparison in order to highlight the significant impact that high valence state Mn4+ and its concentration had on the sample's SCR performance. The experimental findings revealed that the MnCr-3 catalyst outperformed in the LT denitrification reaction and exhibited superior tolerance to sulfur and water. Subsequent studies showed that the MnCr-3 samples with more content of high valence state Mn4+ exhibited superior oxidation performance, promoted oxidation of NO to NO2, and accelerated the SCR reaction course, which was well verified in H2-TPR and O2-TPD datas. Additionally, more abundant high-valent Mn4+ provided richer acidic sites, contributing to NH3 and NOx adsorption, thus accelerating the denitrification process at low temperatures. And the effective electron transfer between Cr6+ and Mn3+can rapidly oxidize Mn3+ to produce more Mn4+ and encourage the regeneration of the highly active species of Mn4+, which makes the MnCr-3 catalyst perform more outstandingly in the LT SCR process. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Preparation of the MnCr-1 catalyst First, a particular amount of deionized water was used to prepare a mixed solution consisting 4.9513 g of Mn(CH3COO)2•4H2O and 8.0838 g of Cr(NO3)3•9H2O at ambient temperature. Next, 10 mL of deionized citric acid monohydrate solution (the molar ratio of citric acid monohydrate to total metal ions was set at 1:1) was slowly added dropwise to the previous mixed solution while vigorous agitating, maintaining agitation up to 2 h to get a homogeneous mixed solution. Subsequently, the mixed solution dissolved with desired amount of polyethylene glycol (PEG-2000) was heated and stirred at 80 °C for 4 h to prepare well-stabilized gel, which dried in a blast oven at 100 °C overnight. At last, the powdered dried material was heated to 450 °C for 4 h in muffle furnace to get the sample (the sample was denoted as MnCr-1). 2.1.2 Preparation of the MnCr-2 catalyst 4.9513 g of Mn(CH3COO)2•4H2O and 8.0838 g of Cr(NO3)3•9H2O were mixed and milled for 30 min. Subsequently, the mixed material was dried and set aside. At the end, the sample was prepared by calcining the dried mixture ground into a fine powder in muffle furnace at 450 °C for 4 h (the sample was denoted as MnCr-2). 2.1.3 Preparation of the MnCr-3 catalyst Firstly, 3.1607 g of KMnO4 and 8.0838 g of Cr(NO3)3•9H2O were dissolved in an appropriate volume of deionized water, respectively, then stirred for 30 min until complete dissolution, to produce solution A and solution B, respectively. Secondly, solution B was gradually incorporated into solution A drop by drop with agitation, and a homogenized solution was obtained by continuously stirring for 1 h Thirdly, the above solution reacted at 80 ℃ for 4 h, cooled, and filtered to obtain solid material. Lastly, the raw material that was gained from washing and drying was ground into powder form and transferred to a muffle furnace for calcination at 450 °C for 4 h to yield the sample (the sample was denoted as MnCr-3). And all details of characterization are listed in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Evaluation of catalyst denitrification performance and tolerance performance 3.1.1 Catalytic activity test Fig. 1 presented the results of the NO elimination in the SCR process for the samples within 75–300 °C. Apparently, the denitrification activities of the three catalysts exhibited similar temperature dependency within the whole reaction process, and all of them first increased to the peak levels as the temperature rose and subsequently reduced. It indicates that in the higher temperature range, the interactions between the active components as well as the motions and collisions of the reactant molecules are enhanced by the energy provided by the temperature increase, which contributes to the conversion of nitrogen oxides and enhanced denitrification abilities. Throughout the complete tested temperature interval, the denitrification activities of the three MnCr catalysts is as follows: MnCr-3 > MnCr-1 > MnCr-2. It can be noticed that the NO conversion of the MnCr-2 catalyst is no <60 % at 75–150 ℃, and the highest NO conversion of it only achieves 93 % at 200 ℃. In addition, the MnCr-1 catalyst shows <70 % NO conversion during the 75–125 °C temperature interval, but reaches 100 % activity at 175 °C. In contrast, the MnCr-3 catalyst exhibits the best LT denitrification activity, displaying approximately 90 % NO conversion at 100 °C, and always maintains over 90 % NO conversion within 100–225 °C. When the reaction temperature exceeded 200 °C, three MnCr samples' activity began to decline. On the one hand, such a phenomenon can be explained by the weakened adsorption of NH3 to acidic sites as well as by ammonia side reactions under high temperatures, causing a reduction of reductant NH3 [24]. On the other hand, it may be explained by the fact that there are thermally-stable nitrates aggregated on the surface of the catalysts, which cannot be decomposed in time to release the active sites, so that the reactive gases fail to react with the catalyst. According to the aforementioned analysis, in the NH3-SCR process, the MnCr-3 catalyst demonstrates better low-temperature denitrification activity. This may be related to the higher content of high-valent Mn4+ in the catalytic system, which facilitates the oxidation of NO to NO2 and promotes the "fast SCR reaction" under low temperatures. This conclusion will be further verified in the subsequent characterization. 3.1.2 The resistance of H2O and SO2 test In practical applications, water and sulfur dioxide toxic impacts are unavoidable, so the water and sulfur resistant properties of three MnCr catalysts were investigated. A measure of the sample's H2O and SO2 resistance is based on the percentage reduction in NO conversion before and after the H2O and SO2 tolerance test of each catalyst. As displayed in Fig. 2 , the NO conversion of three MnCr samples slightly increased within 3 h when exposed to 5 vol% H2O at 225 °C. The result indicates that these catalysts can more efficiently reduce NOx by NH3 with the existence of water vapor, which can be crucial for practical applications. However, with 5 % H2O and 25 ppm SO2 injected at the same time, the MnCr-2 catalyst performance was significantly suppressed, with the NO conversion dropped from 90 % to 21 % within 5 h Similarly, the MnCr-1 catalyst suffered from SO2 poisoning, and the NO conversion marginally declined from 97 % to 86 % within the same time. Compared with MnCr-1, the NO conversion of the MnCr-2 catalyst was drastically reduced after the simultaneous introduction of water and sulfur, probably due to its weaker acidity and deactivation caused by a large amount of SO2 adsorption. On the contrary, the MnCr-3 catalyst catalytic activity changed in a completely different trend. Exposed to 25 ppm SO2, the MnCr-3 catalyst was not deactivated, on the contrary, the NO conversion was slightly enhanced within 5 h This improvement may be because the generated sulfate species increased the catalyst's acidity. This means that MnCr-3 shows excellent durability against sulfur and water compared with the previous two catalysts. Besides, after turning off H2O and SO2, the NO conversion of both MnCr-1 and MnCr-2 catalysts failed to recover to their initial values, suggesting that the coexistence of H2O and SO2 resulted in irreversible activity reduction in both catalysts. One of the reasons, such irreversible deactivation may be explained by the generation of species like (NH4)2SO4 and NH4HSO4 from the reaction of SO2 with NH3 and H2O at low temperatures. These viscous sulfates (especially NH4HSO4) are difficult to decompose at low temperatures ((NH4)2SO4 and NH4HSO4 decompose at 230 °C and 350 °C, respectively), and they can deposit on catalyst surface, block the pores and cover the active ingredients, thus hindering the reactive gases to contact the active components and leading to catalyst deactivation [25]. The reason for this may also account for the over-sulfurization of the surface metal ions to form stable and difficult-to-decompose metal sulfates at this test temperature [26]. To further demonstrate the effect of sulfate formation on catalyst performance, FT-IR tests were performed on fresh samples and samples after water and sulfur resistance tests (Fig. S1). It can be seen that the water and sulfur poisoned MnCr-1 and MnCr-2 catalyst samples showed a more apparent characteristic peak associated with SO4 2− at 1122 cm−1 compared to the fresh samples. This further demonstrates that after the water and sulfur resistance tests, sulfate formation and deposition on the surface of the MnCr-1 and MnCr-2 catalysts covered the active sites, which resulted in a decrease in catalytic activity. In contrast, under the same test conditions, no characteristic peaks associated with sulfate were detected on the surface of the MnCr-3 sample, thus exhibiting better water and sulfur resistance. To investigate the effect of SO2 on the NH3-SCR reaction over the MnCr-3 and the MnCr-2 catalysts, the in situ DRIFTS spectra of NH3+NO+O2 for both catalysts in the presence and absence of SO2 at 200 °C were recorded, and the results are shown in Fig. S2. The experimental results showed that the introduction of SO2 led to the formation of more sulfate species on the surface of the MnCr-2 catalyst, and SO2 also inhibited the NO adsorption as well as the formation of the NH3-SCR reactive nitrogen oxides intermediates to a certain extent due to the competitive relationship between SO2 and NO Meanwhile, the surface sulfate species formed on the catalyst surface by the introduction of SO2 would occupy the active sites of the catalyst, leading to catalyst deactivation, which is consistent with the results of the previous water and sulfur resistance tests of the catalysts. 3.2 Structure of catalysts To determine the phase components of each catalyst, XRD analysis of MnCr-1, MnCr-2, and MnCr-3 was conducted and datas are presented in Fig. 3 . First, discussing the MnCr-1 sample, characteristic peaks of 2θ = 18.12°, 29.89°, 35.11°, 42.86°, 53.22°, 56.67°, and 62.09° can be observed on the XRD patterns. These characteristic peaks matched with the diffraction peaks of Mn1.5Cr1.5O4 (JCPDS card NO 33–0892), which means that this catalyst mainly contains the material phase of Mn1.5Cr1.5O4. As for the MnCr-2 catalyst, the diffraction peaks corresponding to the Mn1.5Cr1.5O4 phase also existed, while the diffraction peaks of 2θ = 18.12°, 24.47°, 33.52°, 35.95°, and 54.80° were attributed to Cr2O3 (JCPDS card NO 38–1479), which implied that this catalyst is mainly composed of Mn1.5Cr1.5O4 and Cr2O3. For the MnCr-3 catalyst, the same stronger peak signals were observed on its XRD pattern, but with different peak positions. The diffraction of 2θ = 12.8°, 18.2°, 41.9°, 49.9°, 60.3°, and 69.6° were attributed to α-MnO2 (JCPDS card NO 44–0141) [27], while the diffraction of 2θ = 28.51°, 37.09°, and 56.23° were assigned to MnCrO4 (JCPDS card NO 33–0893) [28], demonstrating that the catalyst mainly contains MnCrO4 and α-MnO2 phases. Combined with the above phase analysis results, it can be preliminarily determined that among the three catalyst samples, the MnCr-3 catalyst is dominated by the high valence state of Mn4+, while the other two samples are dominated by the lower valence state of Mn3+/Mn2+, which is in line with the expected results of the experimental program set up by us. According to previous studies, Mn4+ is crucial for the LT NH3-SCR process. Specifically, Mn4+ can accelerate the oxidation of NO to NO2 and induce a “fast SCR reaction” at low temperatures to improve catalytic performance [18]. Based on this, plentiful high valence Mn4+ in the MnCr-3 catalyst well explains its best low-temperature denitrification activity among the three samples. 3.3 Surface chemical state As shown in Fig. 4 , XPS test was conducted on MnCr-3 sample in order to further demonstrate the presence of high valence Mn4+ in this sample. Fig. 4(a) demonstrates the XPS spectra of Mn 2p for the MnCr-3 sample, from which two characteristic peaks corresponding to the spin orbitals of Mn 2p3/2 (peak at 642.1 eV) and Mn 2p1/2 (peak at 654.2 eV), respectively, can be identified. And the spectra of Mn 2p can be further deconvoluted into three small peaks, Mn2+ (641.1 eV), Mn3+ (642.4 eV), and Mn4+(643.8 eV), respectively [29,30]. From the Mn 2p spectra deconvolution results, it can be found that Mn species in the MnCr-3 catalyst are majorly dominated by the high valence Mn4+, coinciding with the findings of the XRD tests. According to the previous work, it was reported that Mn4+ could promote oxidation of NO to NO2 to induce an accelerated NH3-SCR process, significantly contributing to the low-temperature denitrification performance [18]. Thus, abundant Mn4+ in the MnCr-3 catalyst well explains the excellent low-temperature SCR performance. Fig. 4(b) demonstrates the XPS spectra of Cr 2p for the MnCr-3 sample, in which the two characteristic peaks near 586 and 576 eV relate to Cr 2p1/2 and Cr 2p3/2, respectively. Here the peaks around 575.5 eV, 576.7 eV, and 579.1 eV are assigned to Cr2+, Cr3+, and Cr6+, respectively [29,31,32]. According to the literature, the variable metal Cr, with the electron transfer between its high valence state Cr5+/Cr6+ ions and Mn3+, favors redox cycling, and thus Cr as an additive is conducive to the optimization of the denitrification performance of manganese-containing catalysts [30,31,33]. XPS spectra associated with O 1 s are demonstrated in Fig. 4(c), where the peak near 529.8 eV is attributed to lattice oxygen (denoted as Oα), while the other peak in the vicinity of the higher binding energy of 531.1 eV is assigned to chemisorbed oxygen (denoted as Oβ) [29,34]. The deconvolution results of O 1 s spectra indicate that the MnCr-3 catalyst is rich in both surface chemisorbed and active lattice oxygens. This will be further demonstrated subsequently by O2-TPD characterization. Further XPS tests were performed on the MnCr-3 catalyst sample after participating in the SCR reaction (labeled as SCR uesd MnCr-3 in Fig. 4). Table S1 summarizes the percentage content of different elemental valence states in the MnCr-3 catalyst before and after the SCR reaction. As can be seen from Fig. 4 and Table S1, the percentage content of Mn3+ on the surface of SCR used MnCr-3 decreased from 38.9 % to 36.9 %, the percentage content of Cr6+ decreased from 17.2 % to 13.9 %. While the percentage content of Mn4+ on the surface of SCR used MnCr-3 increased from 54.4 % to 57.7 %, the percentage content of Cr3+ increased from 47.6 % to 49.8 %, as compared to that of MnCr-3 before the SCR reaction. This demonstrates that there exists an electron transfer process of Cr6+ + Mn3+ ↔ Cr3+ + Mn4+ in the NH3-SCR reaction of the MnCr-3 catalyst, and such electron transfer may be an important reason for the catalyst to exhibit excellent low-temperature NH3-SCR performance. 3.4 Morphology of catalysts SEM tests were applied to analyze the catalyst's morphological characteristics. Fig. 5 presented the SEM graphics of MnCr-1, MnCr-2, and MnCr-3 catalysts, respectively. As shown in Fig. 5(a), the MnCr-1 catalyst presented a sheet-like stacked structure with a smooth surface; Fig. 5(b) exhibited the morphology of the MnCr-2 catalyst, compared with the MnCr-1 catalyst, the MnCr-2 catalyst showed a compact layer stacked structure with irregular nanoparticles attached to the surface. As for the morphology of the MnCr-3 catalyst, something could be noted from Fig. 5(c). Completely different from the other two samples, this catalyst exhibited an urchin-like structure, which consists of spherical cores decorated with evenly scattered nanorods on its surface. Such an urchin-like structure can distribute more active sites, which facilitates full interaction of the reaction gases with catalyst, so greatly improving the NOx removal capability. The conclusions are consistent with the activity test data and well-supported by the NH3-TPD and DRIFTS datas. 3.5 Redox properties of catalysts In general, a catalyst's low-temperature NO removal ability tends to be governed by its redox capacity. To evaluate the redox performance of each MnCr composite oxide catalyst, they were subjected to H2-TPR experiments and datas are presented as curves in Fig. 6 . Firstly, it can be noticed that the MnCr-1 sample demonstrates several distinct peaks around 285 °C, 399 °C, and 459 °C. According to previous literature reports, these peaks represent the sequential reduction process of MnO2 → Mn2O3 → Mn3O4 → MnO, whereas the peak around 350 °C could be interpreted as Cr2O3 being reduced to CrO [29,33,35]. The three reduction peaks of the MnCr-2 sample within 280–438 °C represent a series of MnO2 → MnO reductions with intermediate products Mn2O3 and Mn3O4, while the peak about 351 °C is an overlap of Mn2O3 → Mn3O4 and Cr2O3 → CrO here [29,33,35]. For the MnCr-3 sample, four reduction peaks were observed on its TPR curve, of which the three peaks around 277 °C, 329 °C, and 370 °C represent the multistage reduction process of Mn [32]. In addition, in combination with the previous work, the second peak around 303 °C could be characterized as a reduction of Cr2O3 → CrO [31]. From the TPR spectra, the corresponding H2 consumption of each catalyst is in the order of MnCr-3 > MnCr-1 > MnCr-2, indicating that the MnCr-3 catalyst exposed the largest number of reducible species. The reduction temperature is considered to be a measure of the strength of the catalyst's redox ability, the lower the reduction temperature, the stronger the redox potential. It can be observed that MnCr-3 (277 °C) reduction temperature is slightly lower than that of MnCr-1 (285 °C) and MnCr-2 (280 °C), which indicates that the MnCr-3 catalyst is more easily reduced and exhibits better redox performance. The H2-TPR findings also mean that the higher the Mn ion's valence is, the easier it can be reduced to show good oxidation performance, while the higher content of high valence Mn ions corresponds to better SCR activity. The established papers noted that electron transfer between valence-multivariable metals enhances the catalyst's redox capacity and then improves denitrification activity [36–38]. And the previous XPS analysis results before and after the SCR reaction of the MnCr-3 sample well confirmed the existence of electron transfer interaction between MnOx and CrOx in the MnCr-3 sample, which stabilized the content of high valence state Mn4+ by oxidizing Mn3+ to Mn4+ through the electron transfer path of Cr6+ + Mn3+ ↔ Cr3+ + Mn4+. The high valence state Mn4+ has good redox properties, and the MnCr-3 sample contains abundant high valence state Mn4+, which coincides with the H2-TPR results in which the MnCr-3 sample exhibits excellent redox properties. The electron transfer between Mn and Cr in the MnCr-3 sample promotes the regeneration of the highly active species Mn4+ after the SCR reaction, which facilitates the oxidation of NO to NO2, inducing a “fast SCR” reaction and thus enhancing the low-temperature SCR performance. This may be an important reason for the most prominent ability of this catalyst to remove NOx at low temperatures. Oxygen desorption over each catalyst was studied using O2-TPD and curves are illustrated in Fig. 7 . Generally the lower desorption peaks below 400 ℃ can be attributed to surface chemisorbed oxygen release, the desorption peaks within 400–650 °C can be explained by surface lattice oxygen release, and the peaks over 650 °C can be due to the evolvement of bulk phase lattice oxygen [39,40]. From the O2-TPD curves of all catalysts, it is clearly seen that both MnCr-1 and MnCr-3 catalysts exhibit more obvious desorption peaks of surface chemisorbed oxygen species compared to MnCr-2 catalyst. Commonly, surface chemisorbed oxygen, with better mobility, behaves more actively than other oxygens in the denitrification process. Compared with the MnCr-1 catalyst, the MnCr-3 sample's surface chemisorbed oxygen concentration does not occupy an absolute advantage, indicating that the surface chemisorbed oxygen isn't the major influence on the MnCr-3 catalytic system SCR performance. Similarly, Fang et al. [41] showed that sample's surface chemisorbed oxygen can accelerate catalytic reaction process, but only affects the redox reaction, and cannot completely determine the catalyst denitrification activity separately. Compared with the remaining two catalysts, the MnCr-3 catalyst showed the largest desorption peak area in the range of 400–650 °C, and the peak was obviously shifted to low temperature. This indicates that the MnCr-3 catalyst contains more abundant loosely bound active lattice oxygen. Similarly, it also implies that the MnCr-3 catalyst loses oxygen more easily and exhibits good performance, which in turn suggests that the catalyst has more abundant content of high valence Mn4+. This conclusion is consistent with the previous results of XRD, XPS, and H2-TPR analysis. Combined with the results of the activity tests, it suggests that lattice oxygen may be a key factor influencing the catalytic process of the MnCr-3 catalyst. 3.6 Acidity properties of catalysts Based on the NH3-SCR reaction mechanism, the sample surface acidity strength directly affects the adsorption of reactant NH3, which indirectly impacts the realization of efficient denitrification reaction [42]. Therefore, it is very necessary to discuss the acidic strength of each catalyst here, and in this study, the acid quantity and strength of samples were explored with the NH3-TPD technique. NH3-TPD test results for each sample are displayed in Fig. 8 . Owing to the differences in the adsorption strength and adsorption stability of different reactants NH3 on sample, the NH3-TPD curves of these samples within 100–750 °C can be divided into two parts (with 350 °C as the cut-off point). According to published studies, the desorption peaks in the 100–350 ℃ and 350–750 °C ranges correspond to NH3 desorption on weak and strong acid sites, respectively [43]. Commonly, reactant NH3 adsorbed at weak acids with weak adsorption strength can be smoothly desorbed and take part in catalytic process in the low-temperature stage, whereas, accordingly, reactant NH3 adsorbed at strong acids is more stably adsorbed and mainly participates in denitrification reaction during high-temperature phase. In addition, the peak area on NH3-TPD curve can reveal the acid amount. The magnitude of the total acid amount for the three catalysts is summarized in Table S2. The order of magnitude of the total acid content is: MnCr-3 > MnCr-1 > MnCr-2. The MnCr-3 sample showed obvious desorption peaks at 206 °C, 545 °C and 707 °C, respectively, suggesting that this catalyst has abundant weaker and stronger acid sites, which benefits NH3 adsorption and activation and promotes the denitrification reaction. reaction. Thus, the sample showed superior low-temperature denitrification activity over a broad temperature operating range. Referring to some existing research reports, it can be hypothesized that the presence of more abundant high-valent Mn4+ on MnCr-3 catalyst can offer richer acid sites, which promotes NH3 adsorption, and thus the denitrification performance of this catalyst is more prominent [44]. In contrast, the MnCr-1 catalyst with relatively few weak and strong acid sites showed a significant decrease in activity at temperatures below 150 °C. As for the MnCr-2 catalyst, its fewer surface acidic sites, together with its poor redox properties discussed earlier, explain why its denitrification capability is the lowest throughout the tested temperature interval. In summary, the amount and intensity of acidity on the surface of the three samples are in agreement with their denitrification properties, suggesting that abundant acid sites have a significant effect on the efficient removal of NOx. 3.7 In-situ DRIFT experiments The clarification of the surface species of catalysts and the intermediates that are generated along with the catalytic reaction, as well as the interconversions among these intermediates, are important guidance for studying catalyst reaction mechanisms. Therefore, in situ DRIFTS characterization of all samples was conducted to explore and propose possible reaction mechanisms. 3.7.1 NH3 adsorption-desorption experiment What is well-established and widely acknowledged is that Bronsted acid sites are essential for achieving superior low-temperature denitrification performance. To distinguish the Lewis (L) acid sites from the Brønsted (B) acid sites, NH3 adsorption-desorption experiments were performed. Before introducing the reaction gas NH3 for adsorption, all samples were required to be purified at 300 °C for 30 min under nitrogen atmosphere to exclude interference from impurities. As illustrated in Fig. 9 , when the samples were saturated with adsorbed NH3, some bands were detected. According to previous works, the bands at 1199, 1205, 1232, 1240, 1267, 1508, and 1515 cm−1 can be attributed to NH3 adsorbed on L acid sites, and the bands of 1427, and 1440 cm−1 can correspond to the coordination of NH4 + to B acid sites. The bands of 1355, 1360, and 1592 cm−1 probably relate to the adsorbed NH3 species oxidation [35,45,46]. From Fig. 9(a)-(c), the following conclusions can be obtained: 1) Abundant B and L acids were detected on both MnCr-1 and MnCr-3, but a smaller variety of acidic sites were detected on MnCr-2, which reconfirms the previous NH3-TPD characterization findings. Combined with the activity results demonstrated in Fig. 1, it can be found that MnCr-2 sample catalytic performance is inferior to that of another two catalysts over the whole temperature interval. This experimental fact well confirms that the catalyst's acid strength affects the denitrification performance of the catalyst to some extent. 2) During the programmed temperature increase, it can be noticed that the intensity of the absorption peaks of some L acids (1199, 1205, 1232, and 1240 cm−1) decreased continuously, while the intensity of the absorption peaks of some other L acids (1267, 1508, 1515, and 1592 cm−1) gradually increased, indicating that there are differences in the thermal stability of diverse L acids on sample surface, and they may be involved in different temperatures of the SCR reaction. In addition, some B acids (1427, 1440 cm−1) can be gradually converted to L acids with the increase in temperature. From the above findings, a conclusion can be drawn that the B acid sites mainly function in low-temperature phase, but the L acid sites make significant contributions over the whole temperature range. 3) Relatively abundant L acidic sites were detected on the MnCr-3 catalyst. Considering the findings of H2-TPR and O2-TPD characterization, it can be inferred that abundant high valence Mn4+ on the MnCr-3 catalysts provided more L acidic sites, which improved the NH3 adsorption as well as the catalytic reaction. 4) A large number of past research works have proved that more B acid sites can prevent SO2 adsorption and sulfate deposition, indicating that the B acid sites can significantly enhance the catalyst's tolerance to SO2 [47], which may be a major factor in the excellent sulfur resistance of the MnCr-3 sample. 3.7.2 NO+O2 adsorption-desorption experiment To further analyze the NOx intermediate species of each catalyst during the reaction process, all catalysts were employed in the in-situ DRIFTS test under a mixed NO+O2 atmosphere to obtain more relevant information. Before conducting NO+O2 co-adsorption experiments, purification at 110 °C for 30 min under N2 atmosphere is required. As depicted in Fig. 10 , when the three catalysts are saturated with the adsorption of these two reacting gases (NO+O2), the bands could be observed for monodentate nitrate (1282, 1283, 1286, and 1328 cm−1), bidentate nitrate (1458, 1461, 1513, and 1515 cm−1), bridged nitrate (1695 and 1697 cm−1), the O = N O structure resulted in adsorption of NO+O2 induced asymmetric stretching vibrations (1648 cm−1), gaseous NO2 (1614 cm−1), and free NO3 − (1376 cm−1) [29,45,48–50]. From Fig. 10(a)-(c), the infrared test results of the three catalysts exhibit the following characteristics: 1) with increasing temperature, the infrared signals of monodentate nitrate (1282–1286, 1328 cm−1) progressively weakened and completely disappeared around 200 ℃. Meanwhile, this change process was also coupled with the emergence of bridged nitrate and the production of bidentate nitrate. On the one hand, this may be due to the decomposition of monodentate nitrate, which is not thermally stable, with the increase of temperature; on the other hand, it may be explained by the gradual transformation of monodentate nitrate into more stable bidentate nitrate and bridge nitrate with the increasing temperature. This means that monodentate nitrate may be involved in the denitrification reaction in the temperature range tested. 2) The signal corresponding to NO2 (1614 cm−1) was noticed on MnCr-3 compared to MnCr-1 and MnCr-2 catalysts. According to the literature, the process of NO oxidation accompanied by the generation of gaseous NO2 is essential for LT denitrification because NO2 can evoke a fast SCR reaction, suggesting that MnCr-3 catalyst may be capable of faster and more efficient removal of nitrogen oxides in practical applications and that a “fast SCR reaction” may be taking place on this catalyst [51]. The MnCr-3 catalyst exhibits better redox properties with more Mn4+ in the high valence state, which promotes the formation of NO2 during the oxidation process. 3) Generally, as catalytic denitrification proceeds, if the formed bidentate nitrate species cannot engage in the catalytic process in time because they are overstable, their aggregation and deposition on sample surface can cause active sites with catalytic properties to be covered. This may be an important cause of the SCR performance decrease in higher temperatures for each sample. 3.7.3 NH3+NO+O2 adsorption-desorption experiment For investigating the evolution of sample surface active species as well as intermediates and other substances after the co-adsorption of the three reactive gases on all the samples with increasing temperature and proposing a potential reaction mechanism, all the samples were utilized for in-situ DRIFTS tests of NH3+NO+O2 co-adsorption and spectra were collected, and infrared spectra are presented in Fig. 11 . Before testing, all samples were subjected to catalyst purification using the same method as in the previous in-situ DRIFTS with the NH3 atmosphere alone. As depicted in Fig. 11(a), after saturation of the MnCr-1 sample by adsorbing NH3+NO+O2 at room temperature, the following species were observed: L acid (1246, 1592 cm−1), B acid (1428 cm−1), Oxidized species of adsorbed NH3 (1368 cm−1), monodentate nitrate (1328 cm−1), bidentate nitrate (1468, 1519 cm−1), and bridged nitrate (1692 cm−1) [45,48,50]. A variety of adsorbed NH3 and NOx species can be detected aggregating on MnCr-1 sample. With increasing temperature, bridged nitrate, monodentate nitrate, and NH4 + species decreased, indicating that they are the predominantly reactive species for denitrification, whereas bidentate nitrate is less active and shows better thermal stability. For the MnCr-2 catalyst, displayed in Fig. 11(b), the surface adsorption of the three reactive gases on its surface behaves similarly to that of MnCr-1. However, the corresponding adsorbed NH3 and adsorbed NOx species on MnCr-2 sample after exposure to three reactive gases were relatively reduced compared with those when it adsorbed NH3 alone and co-adsorbed NO+O2. Furthermore, the infrared absorption bands corresponding to bidentate nitrate gradually enhanced as the temperature increased. it can be inferred that the bidentate nitrate might have been progressively deposited to cover the reactive sites of the samples as the temperature continued to rise and the SCR reaction continued to proceed, and the above factors might have affected the catalytic activity of MnCr-2 to some extent. Both MnCr-1 and MnCr-2 catalysts exhibited riched species related to NH3 and NO+O2 adsorption throughout the catalytic process, suggesting that they predominantly follow the Langmuir–Hinshelwood(L-H) mechanism for NOx catalytic elimination. As demonstrated in Fig. 11(c), the following phenomena can be viewed on MnCr-3 catalyst spectra: 1) L acids (1225, 1272 cm−1), B acids (1445, 1655 cm−1), overlapping peaks of NH3 oxide species and free NO3 − (1365 cm−1), bidentate nitrate (1460, 1515 cm−1), gaseous NO2 (1616 cm−1), and bridged nitrate (1697 cm−1) [29,46,49,50]. 2) MnCr-3 surface adsorbed abundant B acid (NH4 +) and NOx species. Among them, bridged nitrate (1697 cm−1), B acids (1445, 1655 cm−1), and gaseous NO2 (1616 cm−1) progressively declined as the temperature increased, implying that they were fully involved in NOx elimination as the primary highly efficient active substances during the SCR process. On the contrary, the band of bidentate nitrate strengthened progressively as temperature increased, suggesting that bidentate nitrates are stable inactive species that gradually aggregate on sample surface with the catalytic denitrification reaction occurs. 3) The bands of bridged nitrate (1697 cm−1), NO2 (1616 cm−1), and NH4 + (1445, 1655 cm−1) dropped significantly when temperature rises from 50 to 100 °C. Combined with activity result of the MnCr-3 catalyst in Fig. 1, it can be noted that the increase in NO conversion at this time is more obvious, which means that the fast SCR reaction can be carried out on the MnCr-3 catalyst at low temperatures. The MnCr-3 catalyst contains more high-valence Mn4+ with excellent redox properties and abundant surface acidic sites, resulting in better low-temperature catalytic properties. 4) NH3 and NO+O2 adsorption behaviors were observed throughout the reaction temperature range revealing that the MnCr-3 mainly obeys the l-H mechanism during the SCR reaction process. 3.7.4 Transient reactions of adsorbed species on the surface of the MnCr-3 catalyst To further confirm the reaction mechanism of the MnCr-3 catalyst, an in situ DRIFT transient reaction was employed to deeply investigate the intermediates of this catalyst in the low-temperature NH3-SCR reaction. First, after the MnCr-3 catalyst was pre-adsorbed with NO+O2 at 125 °C, NH3 was introduced to react with NOx species adsorbed on the catalyst surface. As shown in Fig. 12 (a), after the MnCr-3 catalyst pre-adsorbed NO+O2 at 125 °C, absorption peaks associated with NO+O2 were observed on the catalyst surface: monodentate nitrate (1297 cm−1), bidentate nitrate (1460, 1516 cm−1), and gaseous NO2 (1616 cm−1). As the adsorption time of the fluent NH3 was gradually extended, the following phenomena could be observed: 1) the intensity of the peak of monodentate nitrate (1297 cm−1) gradually weakened until it disappeared. On the one hand, this might be due to the poor thermal stability of monodentate nitrate, which was transformed or decomposed during the reaction. On the other hand, it is likely that the monodentate nitrate is an active species, which might be consumed by the reaction with NH3 adsorbed on the catalyst surface. 2) At 3 min, absorption peaks related to NH3 adsorption began to appear, L acid (1274 cm−1), ammonia oxide species (1365 cm−1), and B acid (1440 cm−1), and these newly appeared absorption peaks gradually enhanced. 3) The intensity of the bidentate nitrate absorption peaks didn't decrease but rather increased throughout the transient reaction, indicating that bidentate nitrate didn't participate in the catalytic reaction. The in situ DRIFT transient spectra between NH3 and pre-adsorbed NO+O2 at 125 °C showed that the catalytic reaction occurring on the surface of the MnCr-3 catalyst follows the l-H mechanism, which is consistent with the reaction mechanism proposed earlier. A similar experimental approach was used to further study the transformation between different adsorbed NH3 species and their reactions with adsorbed NOx species, the in situ DRIFT transient reaction between pre-adsorbed NH3 and NO+O2 was also carried out, and the results are shown in Fig. 12(b). After pre-adsorption of NH3 on the MnCr-3 catalyst at 125 °C, the absorption peaks associated with NH3 were observed on the catalyst surface: the L acid (1199, 1240, and 1592 cm−1), the B acid (1445 cm−1), and the ammonia oxide species (1360 cm−1). With the gradual increase of the adsorption time of the passed NO+O2, the following phenomena can be observed: 1) the intensity of the absorption peaks of B acid (1445 cm−1) and some L acids (1199, 1592 cm−1) gradually weakened until disappeared, while L acid (1240 cm−1) existed throughout the whole reaction process, which indicates that B acid is mainly involved in the catalytic reaction in the low-temperature stage, while L acid plays an important role in both the low-temperature and high-temperature segments of the reaction. 2) The intensity of the absorption peak of the ammonia oxide species (1360 cm−1) was continuously decreasing but always present throughout the transient reaction. 3) At 3 min, the absorption peaks related to NO+O2 adsorption began to appear with monodentate nitrate (1285 cm−1) and bidentate nitrate (1460, 1515 cm−1). It can be seen that the intensity of the absorption peaks of bidentate nitrate increased more significantly. On the one hand, this might be due to the continuous transformation of monodentate nitrate, and on the other hand, it might be attributed to the better stability of bidentate nitrate itself. In summary, the catalytic reaction between the pre-adsorbed NH3 and adsorbed NO+O2 on the MnCr-3 catalyst followed the l-H mechanism, which is consistent with the previously hypothesized reaction mechanism. 3.8 Proposed reaction mechanism Based on the in situ DRIFTS analysis, a possible l-H reaction mechanism for the MnCr-3 catalyst was proposed, as shown in Fig. 13 and Fig. 14 . 4 Conclusions Mn4+ with excellent redox properties is a key active species for low-temperature NH3-SCR reactions. In this work, Cr was introduced to prepare a MnCr bimetallic composite oxide catalytic system, aiming at the regeneration of Mn4+ through the electron transfer pathway between Mn and Cr as a way to stabilize its content. To further highlight the influence of the high valence state Mn4+ and its content on the SCR performance of the catalysts, samples of two other low valence states were prepared for comparison. The experimental results showed that the MnCr-3 sample exhibited good LT denitrification activity (over 90 % NO conversion could be maintained within 100–225 °C) and superior endurance of SO2 and H2O (activity was almost unaffected for 5 h at 225 °C). The XPS results of the MnCr-3 sample before and after the SCR reaction proved the existence of electron transfer between Mn and Cr during the SCR reaction, which was favorable for the valence state recovery of Mn4+ after its participation in the SCR reaction, and realized the low-temperature rapid redox catalytic cycle. And the characterization of XRD, H2-TPR, O2-TPD and NH3-TPD showed that the MnCr-3 catalyst containing abundant Mn4+ exhibited excellent redox properties and acidity. The MnCr-3 catalytic mechanism was deduced and analyzed based on the results of in situ DRIFTS tests. The DRIFTS analysis showed that the MnCr-3 catalyst adsorbed a large amount of NH4 + and NOx species, and followed the l-H mechanism throughout the temperature interval where the denitrification reaction continued. In addition, FT-IR and in situ DRIFTS experiments were performed to analyze the water and sulfur resistance mechanism of the catalysts, and the formation and deposition of sulfate, which covers the active sites, is an important reason for the decrease in activity. coredata.dc:description: Mn4+ shows great potential in low-temperature SCR process due to its excellent redox properties, but Mn4+ is not easy to recover after participating in the SCR reaction, and realizing valence cycling of Mn ions to stabilize the content of high valence Mn4+ is still an urgent problem to be solved. In this work, a high valence Mn4+ catalyst was prepared and Cr was introduced to utilize the electron transfer between Mn and Cr to effectively realize the regeneration and content stabilization of Mn4+. The experimental results showed that the MnCr-3 catalyst with abundant Mn4+ exhibited excellent low-temperature denitrification performance and water and sulfur resistance, and the XPS study demonstrated that the regeneration of Mn4+ was achieved by the presence of electron transfer between Mn and Cr in the SCR reaction of the MnCr-3 catalyst. And a series of characterizations showed that the MnCr-3 catalyst with abundant high-valent Mn4+ exhibited excellent redox properties and acidity. Finally, in situ DRIFTS experiments explored the NH3-SCR reaction mechanism and water and sulfur resistance mechanism of the catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Electron transfer stabilizing highly active species Mn4+ to enhance low-temperature NH3-SCR performance of MnCr composite oxide catalyst
